data.text:
OPENINGS

Columbus area greets

second Swensons site

Swensons Drive-In celebrated the opening of its second Columbus-area restaurant Monday, The Columbus Dispatch reported.

The restaurant, on Ikea Way in the Polaris area, follows the first area Swensons, on Sawmill Road north of Hard Road. A third location, on Cemetery Road in Hilliard, is planned.

The restaurants are the first outside northeast Ohio for the Akron-based chain.

NEWSPAPERS

Gannett turns its back

on Digital First buyout

The publisher of USA Today and dozens of other newspapers said no to a hedge-fund backed media group with a reputation for slashing jobs, but the buyout fight may not be over.

Gannett on Monday said its board has unanimously rejected an unsolicited $1.36 billion buyout from MNG Enterprises, better known as Digital First Media. Digital First, which has a 7.5 percent stake in Gannett, then said that it might nominate new Gannett board directors to consider its offer.

The board decided the $12 per share offer was too low, and that it wasn't in the interest of the company or its shareholders, according to Gannett Co.

"It appears that MNG does not have a realistic plan to acquire Gannett," Gannett said in a prepared statement.

AUTOS

GM begins global layoffs

of white-collar workers

General Motors is starting to lay off about 4,300 white-collar workers worldwide this week.

In November, the company said it wanted to cut 8,000 salaried and contract workers so it can raise profit margins and invest more in autonomous and electric vehicles.

The company says 2,200 white-collar employees took buyouts, while another 1,500 contract workers were let go.

Many of the layoffs will happen at GM's technical center near Detroit. Most work on components for internal combustion engines and discontinued car models.

GM also plans to close one Canadian and four U.S. car factories (including Lordstown in Northeast Ohio), shedding another 5,000 jobs. But 2,700 U.S. workers will be offered jobs at other factories.

EVENTS

PRSA guest panel to talk

about working with media

The Akron Chapter of the Public Relations Society of America will present its annual Working with the Media panel discussion at noon Feb. 14 at The Tangier, 532 W. Market St. in Akron. The luncheon program is open to the public.

The panel moderator will be Cheryl Powell, metro editor of the Akron Beacon Journal. Panelists include Andrew Meyer, news director of WKSU 89.7-FM; Rosalie Murphy, editor of The Devil Strip; and Kelly Petryszyn, editor of Akron Life Magazine. Networking starts at 11:30 a.m. Cost is $25 for PRSA members, $30 for nonmembers and $15 for students. Reservations are required by Friday. and may be made by contacting Lianne Fowler at 330-780-5175 or akronprsa@gmail.com.
